variant.question: Pallets with a tare weight of 160 kg are loaded onto two ground supports. The implication of this is that:

options.text: The total weight of the loaded pallets will be increased by 160 kg.
The ground supports will carry a combined weight of 160 kg.
The total weight of the loaded pallets will be reduced by 160 kg.
The ground supports will be unloaded with a tare weight of 160 kg.

variant.question: The maximum intensity floor loading for an aeroplane is given in the Flight Manual as 650 kg per square metre. What is the maximum mass of a package which can be safely supported on a pallet with dimensions of 80 cm by 80 cm?

options.text: 416 kg

variant.question: What is correct regarding methods for cargo loading?

options.text: Containers can be used only in cargo aircraft, while pallets can also be used in passenger aircraft.
Large cargo is best loaded in pallets.
Containers need their own manifest, while pallets don’t.
Bulk cargo needs less personnel to be loaded.

variant.question: Which of the following loading methods is recommended for the transport of unconventional cargo?

options.text: Large and irregularly shaped cargo can only be loaded in cargo-only aircraft.
Large and irregularly shaped cargo is ideally stored as bulk cargo.
Large and irregularly shaped cargo should be loaded as palletised cargo.
Large and irregularly shaped cargo can best be loaded in containers.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is accurate when comparing the attributes of pallets with those of containers? Pallets...

options.text: do NOT require their own load manifest, while containers do.
are more robust and heavier than containers.
are more suitable than containers for carrying oversized cargo items.
allow for cargo to be more efficiently loaded in the hold than containers do.

variant.question:
Refer to figure or CAP696 Figure 4.9\.   
For the forward cargo compartment (Cargo Hold 1), area between balance arms (BA) 286 in and 343 in, determine which of the 4 boxes may be loaded:

options.text: Box Y: 6.56 kg/inch and 69 kg per ft2
Box X: 8.56 kg/inch and 70 kg per ft2
Box Z: 8.45 kg/inch and 67 kg per ft2
Box W: 8.30 kg/inch and 90 kg per ft2

variant.question: A box weighing 105 kg is loaded into the cargo compartment. Calculate the smallest required floor contact area of this box to avoid exceeding the maximum floor load of 600 kg/m2.

The maximum load per running metre of an aeroplane is 350 kg/m. The width of the floor area is 2 metres. The floor strength limitation is 300 kg per square metre. Which one of the following crates can be loaded directly on the floor?

options.text: A load of 400 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.2 m × 1.2 m × 1.2 m.
A load of 400 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.4 m × 0.8 m × 0.8 m.
A load of 500 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.5 m × 1 m × 1 m.
A load of 700 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.8 m × 1.4 m × 0.8 m.

variant.question: The maximum running load of the aft cargo hold of an aeroplane is 1650 kg/m. Assume the standard mass of the proposed pallet is 120 kg and 2299 kg of baggage have to be loaded in the aft cargo hold. Which of the following pallets (length x width) should be used in order to comply with the running load limit and to optimise best the space in the cargo hold?
Regarding the handling of the cargo, which statement is correct?

options.text: Pallets offer better protection than containers against damage to the aeroplane caused by cargo items.
Containers can be used only in cargo aeroplanes, while pallets can also be used in passenger aeroplanes.
Containers provide better protection than pallets against damage to the cargo items.
Containers have a lighter weight structure when compared to pallets with the same floor dimension.

variant.question: During take-off, the load is suddenly sliding and moving backwards. What happens to the aircraft's CG and stability?

options.text: CG moves aft and stability increases.
CG moves forward and stability increases.
CG moves forward and stability decreases.
CG moves aft and stability decreases.

variant.question:
Refer to figure or CAP696 Figure 4.9\.   
 For the forward cargo compartment (Cargo Hold 1), area between balance arms (BA) 286 in and 343 in, determine the (1) maximum running load, (2) maximum distribution load intensity and (3) the maximum load:
Which one of the following statements is true?

options.text: Running load is the maximum load tolerated per unit of area (i e kg/m2).
The orientation of a specified cargo container within a cargo hold will not affect the running load.
Cargo may be loaded into a passenger compartment, provided that it is secured according to applicable regulations in EU-OPS 1.
The floor loading limit is equal to MTOM-BEM.

variant.question: Considering the methods of loading cargo, which of the following answers is correct?

options.text: Containers lock directly into the aircraft’s restraint system and have their own manifest.
Compared to pallets, bulk cargo is quicker to load and requires fewer ground personnel.
Pallets are used on smaller aircraft and must be strapped down to tie-down points.
Bulk cargo is secured onto unit load devices using nets.

variant.question:
Refer to figure or CAP696 Figure 4.9.  
For the aft cargo compartment (Cargo Hold 4), area between balance arms (BA) 940 in and 997 in, determine the (1) maximum running load, (2) maximum distribution load intensity and (3) the maximum load:
